bibl.title: Despatch from William H. Heard to Richard Olney, December 22, 1896
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, Dec 22, 1896.

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D. FEB 8 1897 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: William H. Heard, to the Department of State.
Subject:
Advice of the demise of Hattie Gibson of Martinsburg W. Va
Legation of the United States Monrovia, Liberia, Dec 22, 1896.
Hon., Richard Olney, Secretary of State, Washington D. C.

Sir: I have the honor to perform the painful duty of advising you of the death of Miss Hattie Gibson of Martinsburg, W. Va. U. S. A. who was sent out here in Oct. 1895, as a teacher by the "Colonization Society." She has spent much of the time at Muhlenberg Mission in Montserrado County on the St. Paul River. Teaching sewing. The cause of her death, the certificate of the physician says was blood poisoning.
I am obediently, William H. Heard Minister Res. and Consul General

p.del: I am very obediently Minister Res. and Consul General

div1.p: Enclosure
Inventory of the effects of Hattie Gibson
